definition[0]: having very serious or worrying results
example[0]: There is a major problem with parking in London.
example[1]: The loss of their goalkeeper through injury was a major setback for the team.
example[2]: He underwent major heart surgery recently.
example[3]: It could have sparked a major confrontation.
definition[1]: very large or important, when compared to other things or people of a similar kind
example[4]: There are two major political parties in the US.
example[5]: The government’s major concern is with preventing road accidents.
example[6]: Smoking is one of the major causes of cancer.
example[7]: the major developments in computer technology
example[9]: Britain played a major role in the negotiations.
example[10]: This is major? You got me out of bed for this?
definition[3]: a major key is based on a musical scale in which there are semitones between the third and fourth and the seventh and eighth notes
definition[4]: an officer of middle rank in the British or US army or Marines, or in the US air force
definition[5]: the main subject that a student studies at college or university
definition[6]: someone studying a particular subject as their main subject at college or university
definition[7]: very large or important when compared with other companies, countries, activities etc of a similar kind
example[15]: a meeting of the seven major industrialized nations
example[16]: The company is currently undergoing a major restructuring.
example[17]: The company’s major problem was its reliance on the big UK market.
example[18]: There are no major safety concerns with this product.
definition[9]: a very important company in a particular industry
example[19]: The majors are taking market share away from smaller companies.
